docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Without Health Benefits, a Good Life Turns Fragile'' (front page, March 5): I am the medical director of a small program that focuses on uninsured and medically fragile patients. Most of my patients are impoverished. Those who are not are struggling. Some used to be what we refer to as middle-class.

headline.main: Fighting Disease, and Then the Bills

docs.abstract: Six letters respond to March 5 article about growing ranks of Americans without health insurance; Dr Douglas Binder describes working with impoverished patients; Robert Jaffe focuses on health insurance companies that refuse to cover those who are ill; Kate Brophy says her son has mild illness but is considered uninsurable by main insurance providers; Vahe A Tiryakian says health insurance should be public instead of private; Wayne Nelson, president of Communicating for America, describes plan by some states to establish insurance pools for 'high-risk' clients; David Vanderpool says uninsured pay higher prices; drawing

docs.lead_paragraph: After the bids and the counterbids and the court battle, the two suitors clashing over Caremark Rx threw what each hoped would be the knockout blow in the battle. Both CVS and Express Scripts increased their offers for the company, the nation's largest drug benefits manager, in the latest round in a three-month match.

docs.lead_paragraph: ALBANY, March 8 — Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo sent letters to about 100 public authorities on Thursday warning them that their trustees should not be receiving free health insurance because they are supposed to serve without compensation.

headline.main: End Health Perks for Public Trustees, Cuomo Says
headline.print_headline: End Health Perks for Public Trustees, Cuomo Says

docs.snippet: ALBANY, March 8 — Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo sent letters to about 100 public authorities on Thursday warning them that their trustees should not be receiving free health insurance because they are supposed to serve without compensation.
